_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Applied Chemical Technology, Inc. (ACT) is dedicated to preventing an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from its on-site ammonia tank. The tank contains more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, therefore it is considered a level 3 program. 



ACT believes that the health, safety, and preservation of our environment are critical to business success. We are committed to:



Providing a safe work environment for employees and visitors.

Conducting business with respect to the community.

Meeting or exceeding environmental health & safety laws and regulations.

Training employees on how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.



The anhydrous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel on the property. The ammonia tank is equipped with safety relief valves that are designed to release pressure if the tank becomes over pressurized. The tank is also equipped with excessive flow valves that are designed to shut down the flow of ammonia if a sudden release should occur. The tank and the distribution system are equipped with appropriate pressure relief devices which are routed to a scrubber to minimize emissions to the atmosphere. 



The worst-case release scenario for the tank was calculated using RMP-Comp. An alternative release scenario for the tank was calculated using RMP-Comp that involved a pipe leak. This would be quickly detected by operating personnel and quickly controlled by a combination of operating procedures and excess flow valves. 



In the event of a release that could impact the community, ACT advises those in the area to shelter in place until the plume dissipates. This involves shutting the windows and turning off the air conditioning and other ventilation systems. Employees on site at ACT are instructed to follow the evacuation procedures outlined in the emergency action plan. 



No reportable accidents have occurred at this site within the last 5 years. 



Employees involved with the process are trained in proper handling procedures for anhy

drous ammonia. They are provided with the proper personal protective equipment for routine handling of the material. The training also covers the steps in responding to emergencies involving ammonia releases and are available to assist the community first responders with information. The employees are considered limited first responders in that they will handle any leak or spill they judge to be within their capabilities and training, but are instructed in case of a major incident to activate the site emergency action plan and to call for trained responders. 



ACT employees are trained in proper handling, inspections, ammonia characteristics, and emergency procedures. Employees must review the emergency action plan annually.
